column1: Papillion is a city in Sarpy County in the state of Nebraska
column2: United States. Designated as the county seat
column3: it developed as an 1870s railroad town and suburb of Omaha. The city is part of the larger five-county metro area of Omaha. Papillion's population was 18
column4: 894 at the 2010 census. Its growth since the late 20th century has reflected Omaha's.

column1: The city was named after the creek of the same name which flows through its center; this had been named by early French explorers
column2: as France had claimed this territory through the eighteenth century. The name Papillion is derived from the French term (papillon) for butterfly. According to local tradition
column3: the early French explorers named the creek as Papillon because they saw so many butterflies along its grassy banks. The spelling was changed through a transliteration of the French word.

column1: Papillion was platted in 1870 when the railroad was extended to that point. Papillion (sometimes referred to as "Papio" by its residents) is one of the last of the late 18th-century
column2: Paris-inspired frontier cities left in the Midwestern United States.

column1: Papillion has a Triple-A minor league baseball team. Werner Park
column2: located (5 km) west of the city on Highway 370 in unincorporated Sarpy County
column3: opened in 2011 as the new home of the Omaha Storm Chasers of the Pacific Coast League. The Storm Chasers were formerly the Omaha Royals; after 42 years at Rosenblatt Stadium in south Omaha
column4: the team moved out following the 2010 season and changed their nickname. They have been the only AAA-affiliate of the Kansas City Royals
column5: an expansion club that entered the American League in 1969.

column1: Papillion is divided into four wards
column2: with two councilmembers elected from each. One seat for each ward is up for election every two years
column3: with each term lasting four years.  The mayor is the head of the city council and is elected at-large to four-year terms.  The council meets every two weeks.  Following former Mayor James Blinn's resignation on July 7
column5: city council president David Black succeeded to become mayor of Papillion.  He was elected in 2010 for his first full term.

Papillion is part of the Papillion-La Vista Public School District
column3: three middle schools and fifteen public elementary schools. Papillion-La Vista South High School
column4: the newer of the two high schools
